questions.text: Identify the fracture in given diagram.
questions.solution:
The radius commonly gets fractured about 2 cm above its lower end (Colles' fracture).

This fracture is caused by a fall on the outstretched hand

The distal fragment is displaced upwards and backwards, and the radial styloid process comes to lie proximal to the ulnar styloid process. (It normally lies distal to the ulnar styloid process.)

If the distal fragment gets displaced anteriorly, it is called Smith's fracture.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 1, 8th Edition, Page No 21

questions.text: Identify the following device.
questions.solution:
Transcranial Direct-Current Stimulation (tDCS) is a portable, wearable brain stimulation technique that delivers a low electric current to the scalp. A fixed current between 1 and 2 mA is typically applied. tDCS works by applying a positive (anodal) or negative (cathodal) current via electrodes to an area.

tDCS is a neuromodulation technique that produces immediate and lasting changes in brain function. The position of the anode and cathode electrodes on the head is used to set how current flows to specific brain regions. The current delivered by tDCS is NOT strong enough to trigger an action potential in a neuron instead it is 'sub-threshold' that changes the pattern of already activity neurons. Think of the brain as active, trying to do or learn something, and tDCS coming along to boost this ongoing activity. At the cellular level, tDCS changes neuronal firing and by strengthening synaptic transmission between neurons by augmenting synaptic plasticity which is, in turn, the cellular basis of learning.

tDCS is often combined with training. Training in itself produces learning (synaptic plasticity), and concurrent tDCS amplifies these effects (enhances synaptic plasticity).

Some clinical applications tDCS is currently being explored for are depression, schizophrenia, aphasia, addiction, epilepsy, chronic pain (migraine, fibromyalgia), attention, and motor rehabilitation. tDCS is also used for non-medical wellness applications, for example accelerated learning, focus, relaxation, and meditation.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 343, 346, 373, 1418

questions.text: The most common complication of following type of cataract is -
questions.solution:
Above image shows the Morgagnian type of hypermature cataract.

Hypermature cataract - has two varieties

  • Nuclear sclerotic cataract: The lens becomes shrunken and small with calcification on the anterior capsule. There is wrinkling of the lens capsule. It predisposes to subluxation of lens


  • Morgagnian cataract: There is total liquefaction of the cortex as a result of which the nucleus sinks inferiorly. The liquefied cortex leaks through the intact capsule and blocks the trabecular meshwork. This leads to phacolytic glaucoma or lens protein glaucoma. It also causes phacoanaphylactic uveitis.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 199

questions.text: This 3-month-old infant presented with lethargy, poor feeding and mild jaundice. What is the diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
In early infant life, babies with hypothyroidism are usually asymptomatic and show no clinical signs. Important features include umbilical hernia, wide posterior fontanelles, goiter at birth or later, placidity, sleepiness, poor feeding, constipation, hypothermia, peripheral cyanosis, oedema and prolonged physiological jaundice.

More specific features include coarse facial features, dry skin, large tongue, hoarse cry and low hairline, which are all late signs.

Causes of congenital hypothyroidism are thyroid dysgenesis, dyshormonogenesis and hypothalamic pituitary congenital hypothyroidism. FSH and T4 levels will be low in dysgenesis and dyshormonogenesis cases.

Screening is to detect hypothyroidism, as treating these conditions early will have a benefit on the child's life. However, no screening program is 100% specific and sensitive.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 2668

questions.text: Identify the following organism.
questions.solution:
This image is of HIV. Because it has 2 RNAs, other GP120, GP41, are present only in HIV.

HIV belongs to the family of human retroviruses. It is also known as Human T cell Lymphotropic virus.

The nucleocapsid has an outer icosahedral shell and an inner cone shaped core enclosing the ribonucleoprotein.

Its genome is diploid. Reverse transcriptase enzyme is present.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 571

questions.text: A 76 years old female was taking an anti-cancer drug for breast carcinoma. Later she presented with the palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia as shown in the figure below. Which of the following drugs is the most likely to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
The figure shows Hand and Foot syndrome which is a characteristic adverse effect of 5-fluorouracil, doxorubicin and capecitabine.

Adverse Effects of doxorubicin -

Myelosuppression is a major dose-limiting complication, with maximal leukopenia usually occurring during the second week of therapy and recovering by the fourth week; thrombocytopenia and anemia follow a similar pattern but usually are less pronounced.

Stomatitis, mucositis, diarrhea, and alopecia are common but reversible. Erythematous streaking near the site of infusion ('flare') is a benign local allergic reaction and should not be confused with extravasation. Facial flushing, conjunctivitis, and lacrimation may occur rarely.

The drug may produce severe local toxicity in irradiated tissues (e.g., the skin, heart, lung, esophagus, and GI mucosa) even when the two therapies are not administered concomitantly.

Cardiomyopathy is the most important long-term toxicity

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1191

questions.text: All of the following are minor criteria for the diagnosis of the disease shown in the image, except -
questions.solution:
The image shows vegetations (arrows) due to viridans streptococci endocarditis

involving the mitral valve.

Modified Duke's criteria are useful for the diagnosis of Infective endocarditis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1023

questions.text: Tzanck smear is used in the diagnosis of -
questions.solution:
HSV -

  • Tzanck smear is used to diagnose Herpes simplex virus.
  • Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells.
  • Giemsa stain shows Cowdry A intranuclear inclusion bodies, which have granular appearance.
  • HSV infection is best confirmed by isolation of the virus in human diploid fibroblast.
  • PCR for HSV DNA is most sensitive test.
  • Treatment of choice is acyclovir.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition Page no 477

choices.text: Air fluid level due to intestinal obstruction

questions.text: A 35 years old male patient had complained of pain in the right iliac fossa, high grade fever, malaise, anorexia and generalized weakness for 5 days. He did not take treatment for this. Today he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe abdominal pain. He presents to you in the emergency and his chest X ray is taken which is shown below. What finding is seen in the CXR?
questions.solution:
This patient had a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis and had not taken treatment for the same. So, the appendix might rupture and produce secondary peritonitis.

On standing Chest X Ray shows gas under the diaphragm which suggests bowel perforation.

Gas under the diaphragm is called pneumoperitoneum.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1055

questions.text: A 35 years old man is suffering from pneumonia. The sputum smear is shown below. The most likely causative agent is -
questions.solution:
Acid fast (red coloured) filamentous organism is Nocardia.

Nocardia is weakly gram-positive catalase positive rod-shaped bacteria. It forms partially acid -fast beaded branching filaments. It contains a total of 85 species. Some species are non-pathogenic, while others are responsible for nocardiosis.

Mostly it causes opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. Pulmonary nocardiosis and disseminated forms of the infection are opportunistic diseases and occur mainly in patients deficient in T cell mediated immunity.

Respiratory secretion, skin biopsy sample and aspirates from the abscess are the most common specimens from which nocardia species are identified.

Nocardia species can usually be isolated in 3-5 days.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 400

choices.text: It can be used to visualize the entire small bowel
It is suitable for patients with strictures

questions.text: All are advantages of the following device, except -
questions.solution:
The device being referred to likely has a narrow diameter and may not pass easily through strictures or narrow areas of the bowel.

Other Options:

It can be used to visualize the entire small bowel (Option A): This is an advantage, as it allows for comprehensive examination of the small bowel.

No sedation is required (Option B): This is an advantage, as sedation can carry risks and may not be needed for the procedure.

Painless (Option C): This is an advantage, as a painless procedure is generally more comfortable for the patient.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 153

questions.text: A 40 years old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2 complains of difficulty in urination, flank pain, high grade fever, nausea and vomiting. The following image shows the CECT of his abdomen pelvis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CECT shows emphysematous changes around the right kidney.

Emphysematous pyelonephritis is most common in the diabetic patients.

Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a particularly severe form of the disease that is associated with the production of gas in renal and perinephric tissues and occurs almost exclusively in diabetic patients.

Option A - Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis occurs when chronic urinary obstruction (often by staghorn calculi), together with chronic infection, leads to suppurative destruction of renal tissue.

Option C - In Renal cell carcinoma, the kidney size is enlarged and irregular.

Option D - IN ADPKD, multiple cysts are present in the pole of the kidney.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1073

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for developing the most frequent complication of the given procedure except -
questions.solution:
The presence or absence of a common bile duct (CBD) stone is not a risk factor for the development of the most frequent complication of the given procedure.

Other Options:

Suspected SOD dysfunction (Option A): Suspected sphincter of Oddi (SOD) dysfunction can contribute to the development of the most frequent complication of the procedure.

Female sex (Option B): Female sex can be a risk factor for developing the most frequent complication.

Low volume of procedure performed (Option C): A low volume of the procedure being performed can increase the risk of complications.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 155, 156

choices.text: Direct invasion of the optic nerves
Ischemic infarct due to hypercoagulable state

questions.text: A 40 years old female patient had complaints of visual loss, headache for 1 month. The MRI Brain shows pituitary adenoma. Which of the following is not a mechanism for her visual loss?
questions.solution:
Suprasellar extension can lead to visual loss by several mechanisms, the most common being compression of the optic chiasm. Rarely, direct invasion of the optic nerves or obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow leading to secondary visual disturbances can occur.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2902

questions.text: What is the diagnosis on exploration of scrotum for scrotal pain?
questions.solution:
Torted and infarcted hydatids refers to a torsion (twisting) of the appendix testis or hydatid of Morgagni, leading to infarction and pain.

Other Options:

Torsion of testis (Option A): While also a cause of scrotal pain, the image depicted in the question might be more indicative of torted and infarcted hydatids.

Epididymo-orchitis (Option B): Epididymo-orchitis is inflammation of the epididymis or testis, which can also cause scrotal pain.

Testicular tumor (Option D): Testicular tumors can cause pain or discomfort, but the question seems to be referring to a specific scenario involving torted and infarcted hydatids.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 259

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
Colposcope -

  • A binocular microscope to study the epithelium of the lower anogenital tract under illumination and magnification.
  • Application of acetic acid 3-5% acetic acid is applied with cotton balls held by a sponge holder.
    • Acetic acid precipitates protein (clumps nuclear chromatin) and abnormal epithelium appears white called acetowhite (AW) change.
  • Application of Schiller's iodine
    • Normal epithelium is mahogany or black due to glycogen content.
    • Dysplastic epithelium is mustard or saffron yellow because it is glycogen free.
    • Iodine uptake is only in glycogen containing squamous epithelium as iodine is glycolytic.
  • Endocervical curettage and biopsy is taken, if it is required.
  • Findings are documented satisfactory or unsatisfactory (if SCJ is seen or not).
  • Normal findings:
    • Normal columnar epithelium is red grape-like.
    • Normal squamous epithelium is homogeneous grey.
  • Insignificant findings:
    • Acetowhite epithelium is shiny or semi trans- parent.
    • Borders are not sharp.
    • Vessels: Fine punctuation, fine mosaic, ICD (intercapillary distance) is short.
  • Abnormal findings significant:
    • Dense acetowhite area with sharp border. Appears faster and lasts longer.
    • Vessels are dilated, irregular or coiled (coarse punctuation and mosaic) atypical vessels.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: Name the marked tract.
questions.solution:
The image indicates the spinal cord and its tracts.

The marked tract corresponds to the Lateral Corticospinal Tract. This descending motor pathway originates in the cerebral cortex and is responsible for voluntary motor control of the limbs. It crosses to the contralateral side of the spinal cord at the medullary pyramids (pyramidal decussation).

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No 44, 45

choices.text: Genital tract laceration is the commonest cause of the condition
This condition is the commonest cause of maternal mortality
Access to anesthesia may influence the outcome of the management of this condition

questions.text: Concerning the condition being treated with this intervention, false statement is -
questions.solution:
Postpartum hemorrhage -

  • Management -
  • General Measures - Including Resuscitative Measures + Investigations + Confirmation of Diagnosis
  • The first and basic step in the management of PPH is resuscitation of the patient which includes:
  • Securing I/V lines
  • Volume restoration by crystalloids (normal saline / Ringer lactate)
  • Oxygen inhalation
  • Crossmatching and arranging for blood.
  • At the same time investigations like Blood group, Hemoglobin, Clotting time, Coagulation profile, Electrolytes should be sent
  • The Cause of PPH i.e., whether it is atonic (diagnosed by abdominal palpation) or traumatic should be looked and managed accordingly.
  • When diagnosis of Atonic PPH is confirmed - Uterus should be massaged continuously and medical methods should be adopted.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 654

questions.text: Name the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The image shows the cerebral arteries and their branches.

The marked artery corresponds to the Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA), which is responsible for supplying blood to the posterior part of the brain, including the occipital lobe and portions of the temporal and parietal lobes.

Reference: Cunningham's Manual of Practical Anatomy, Volume - 3, 16th Edition, Page No 293

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes intestinal pathology shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
This is a typical flask shaped ulcer, seen in intestinal amebiasis.

E. histolytica causes amoebic dysentery.

Cyst and trophozoite are two forms of parasite.

All pathogenicity is due to the trophozoite.

It produces a flask shaped ulcer in the intestine. Rarely this ulcer ruptures and produces intestinal perforation.

Apart from intestinal amoebiasis, extra intestinal amoebiasis is also common.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 17,18, 19, 21, 24

questions.text: A 30 years old prostitute has the following lesion near anus. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is condyloma lata. It is seen in secondary syphilis. It is caused by T pallidum. Syphilis can present as either primary, secondary, latent or tertiary.

  • In primary, primary chancre is seen, single painless, indurated
  • In secondary syphilis initial lesion is non pruritic macule, condylomata lata, mucous patches are seen
  • In tertiary syphilis cardiovascular involvement, neurological involvement, skin, skeletal system, larynx, liver and stomach is involved.
  • In latent syphilis - there is a positive serological test with absence of clinical manifestation.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 18th Edition, Page no 1382

questions.text: Identify the following drug based on the mechanism of action provided in the given figure below.
questions.solution:
As shown in the diagram, the drug is inhibiting the exocytosis of ACh.

Botulinum toxin acts by this mechanism. Other features of botulinum toxin are:

  • Anticholinergic adverse effects (dry mouth, blurring of vision)
  • Use in wrinkles, spastic disorders, prophylaxis of migraine.

Botulinum toxin A and B are highly potent exotoxins produced by Clostridium botulinum that are responsible for 'botulism' (a type of food poisoning). These neurotoxic proteins cause long-lasting loss of cholinergic transmission by interacting with axonal proteins involved in exocytotic release of ACh.

Localized injection of minute quantity of botulinum toxin A (BOTOX) or its haemagglutinin complex (DYSPORT) can be used in the treatment of a number of spastic and other neurological conditions like blepharospasm, spastic cerebral palsy, strabismus, spasmodic torticollis, nystagmus, hemifacial spasm, post stroke spasticity, spasmodic dysphonia, axillary hyperhidrosis, etc. which are due to overactivity of cholinergic nerves.

It is being employed popularly as a beauty treatment for removal of age-related facial wrinkles. However, incorrect injection or overdose can be dangerous; ptosis, diplopia, facial swelling, dry mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, muscular weakness and even respiratory paralysis has occurred.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 111

choices.text: Ball and socket variety of synovial joint

questions.text: Identify the type and subtype of the marked joint.
questions.solution:
The incudomalleolar joint is a saddle joint.

The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket joint.

Both of them are synovial joints.

They are surrounded by capsular ligaments.

Accessory ligaments are three for the malleus, and one each for the incus and the stapes which stabilize the ossicles.

All ligaments are extremely elastic



Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page No 292, 293

questions.text: Sign seen below is seen in -
questions.solution:
Above image shows Shafer's sign seen in Rhegmatogenous RD.

Rhegmatogenous RD

  • The essential lesion is a rhegma (retinal break) through which the liquefied vitreous gains access to the retina. This liquefied vitreous accumulates beneath the neurosensory retina leading to RD.

Symptoms

  • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreo-retinal traction at site of break
  • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous hemorrhage
  • Visual field defect which is described by the patient as a black curtain or veil in front of the eye.
  • Loss of vision when the detachment involves the macula.

Signs

  • Decrease in visual acuity
  • Hypotony: The liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE leading to hypotony
  • Shafer's sign: Pigments in anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh RD
  • Detached retina is convex in configuration. Surface is corrugated with free undulation. Break is identified at the periphery.

Reference: Ophthalmology - Jay S. Duker & Myron Yanoff, 4th edition, Pg 649

questions.text: The below image shows CT angiogram illustrating loss of circulation to the upper pole of the right kidney. All of the following condition can cause this type of presentation except?
questions.solution:
The presented CT angiogram shows a loss of circulation to the upper pole of the right kidney, indicating reduced blood flow to that area.

While a hypercoagulable state can increase the risk of clot formation (thrombosis) in various blood vessels, including the renal arteries, it is not specifically related to the presented CT angiogram showing loss of circulation to the upper pole of the right kidney.

Atherosclerosis of the renal artery (Option A), embolism due to atrial fibrillation (Option C), and subacute bacterial endocarditis (Option D) can all cause reduced blood flow to the kidneys due to various mechanisms.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2089

questions.text: Which type of inguinal hernia repair is seen below?
questions.solution:
Inguinal hernia repair is a surgical procedure to correct a hernia that occurs in the groin region, where a portion of abdominal tissue protrudes through a weakened area in the abdominal wall.

The image appears to represent Lichtenstein's repair, a commonly performed technique for inguinal hernia repair. Lichtenstein's repair involves the placement of a mesh patch over the weakened area of the abdominal wall to reinforce and support the hernia site.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1069

choices.text: Prosthetic graft placement in all symptomatic aortic aneurysm

questions.text: A 25 years old male patient is known case of Marfan syndrome. His MRI Aortogram shows Fusiform Aneurysm in Ascending Aorta. Which statement is false regarding management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In Marfan syndrome, aortic prophylactic surgery is recommended if the ascending aorta reaches a diameter of 4.5 cm or more, not 2.5 cm. Prophylactic surgery is not solely based on size but also considers the rate of growth, the patient's symptoms, and other factors.

Management options for aortic aneurysms in Marfan syndrome:

  • Beta-blockers (Option A) are often prescribed to slow down the heart rate and reduce blood pressure, which helps to decrease the stress on the aortic wall.
  • ACE inhibitors (Option B) can also be used to manage blood pressure and reduce the risk of aortic complications.
  • Prosthetic graft placement (Option D) is indicated for symptomatic aortic aneurysms and for aneurysms that are rapidly growing or at risk of rupture, regardless of symptoms.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2103

choices.text: On pump coronary artery by pass
Off -pump coronary artery bypass using octopus stabiliser

questions.text: Which procedure is going on?
questions.solution:
Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is a surgical procedure used to improve blood flow to the heart muscle when the coronary arteries are narrowed or blocked.

The image appears to depict an off-pump coronary artery bypass procedure using an Octopus stabilizer. In this approach, the heart is not stopped ("off-pump"), and an Octopus stabilizer is used to hold a specific portion of the heart steady during surgery. This stabilizer helps the surgeon perform precise grafting of the blocked or narrowed coronary arteries.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 953

questions.text: A 40 years old male with a history of cirrhosis presented with a new onset of fever and lower neck pain. He has a history of IV drug use. Jaundice and a painful swollen area over his left sternoclavicular joint. Patient was diagnosed with septic monoarthriris. Which joint is less commonly involved in septic arthritis in I.V. drug abuse?
questions.solution:
Patients with acute septic arthritis usually present with joint pain aggravated by movement, joint swelling, and/or erythema.

Approximately 90% of patients present with involvement of a single joint-most commonly the knee; less frequently the hip; and still less often the shoulder, wrist, or elbow.

Small joints of the hands and feet are more likely to be affected after direct inoculation or a bite.

Among IV drug users, infections of the spine, sacroiliac joints, and sternoclavicular joints are more common than infections of the appendicular skeleton.

Polyarticular infection is most common among patients with rheumatoid arthritis and may resemble a flare of the underlying disease. The usual presentation consists of moderate to severe pain that is uniform around the joint, effusion, muscle spasm, and decreased range of motion.

Fever in the range of 38.3-38.9°C (101-102°F) and sometimes higher is common but may not be present, especially in persons with rheumatoid arthritis, renal or hepatic insufficiency, or conditions requiring immunosuppressive therapy.

The inflamed, swollen joint is usually evident on examination except in the case of a deeply situated joint such as the hip, shoulder, or sacroiliac joint. Cellulitis, bursitis, and acute osteomyelitis, which may produce a similar clinical picture, should be distinguished from septic arthritis by preservation of passive range of motion and less-than-circumferential swelling. A focus of extraarticular infection, such as a boil or pneumonia, should be sought. Peripheral-blood leukocytosis with a left shift and elevation of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate or C-reactive protein level are common.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1041

questions.text: Which method of breast examination is seen below?
questions.solution:
The dial clock method, also known as the clock face method, is a technique used for the systematic examination of the breast tissue to detect any abnormalities or changes.

The image depicts the dial clock method of breast examination. In this method, the breast is divided into imaginary segments resembling the numbers on a clock face. Healthcare professionals use this technique to ensure thorough and organized examination of different regions of the breast.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 916

questions.text: A 17 years old female patient had short stature, infertility, underdeveloped breast and primary amenorrhea. Her karyotype is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The karyotype shows that 45X0 chromosome. One X chromosome is absent. So, the diagnosis is Turner's syndrome.

TS is characterized by female external genitalia, short stature, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, infertility, and other phenotypic features.

Infants may present with lymphedema, nuchal folds, low hairline, or left-sided cardiac defects or later in childhood with unexplained growth failure or delayed puberty.

Although limited spontaneous pubertal development occurs in up to 30% of girls with TS (10%, 45,X; 60%, 45,X/46,XX) and up to 20% have menarche, the vast majority of women with TS develop complete ovarian insufficiency.

Therefore, this diagnosis should be considered in all women who present with primary or secondary amenorrhea and elevated gonadotropin levels.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3000

questions.text: Identify the pathological specimen of a brain tumour given below?
questions.solution:
• Glioblastoma multiforme is a highly malignant brain tumor that originates from glial cells in the central nervous system.
  • The given pathological specimen is consistent with the appearance of glioblastoma multiforme.
  • It is characterized by its aggressive and invasive nature, often showing areas of necrosis, irregular borders, and marked cellular pleomorphism.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 715

choices.text: Restricted diffusion involving the right medial temporal lobe and hippocampus
Patient had infarct in Right temporal lobe
Herpes simplex encephalitis may be suspected

questions.text: A 30 years old female patient presented to the emergency ward with altered sensorium and a high-grade fever with convulsions. Her MRI Brain is shown below. What is a false statement regarding this image?
questions.solution:
MRI shows restricted diffusion involving the right medial temporal lobe and hippocampus.

Patient had no complains of any limb weakness. Patient is young and has no comorbidities that likely responsible for stroke.

As the patient had complaint of fever, convulsion and altered sensorium likely suggest the diagnosis of encephalitis.

Herpes simplex virus produced encephalitis mostly in the Temporal lobe and Hippocampus.

For diagnosis confirmation, CSF analysis and microscopy and CSF HSV PCR are done.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3287

questions.text: DWI-MRI of a patient presenting with fever and seizure is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brain Abscess:

A brain abscess is a localized collection of pus within the brain tissue, often caused by bacterial or fungal infections. The symptoms of fever and seizure, along with the findings on DWI-MRI, can be indicative of a brain abscess. The restricted diffusion seen on DWI-MRI can be attributed to the cellular debris and inflammation within the abscess.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 707

questions.text: The instrument shown in the figure is used to measure -
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a goniometer, which is used to measure baseline urethral angle and maximum strain angle of the urethra with a cotton tip swap in place.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th Edition, Page no 226

choices.text: Surgical exploration of the femoral and popliteal artery through a medial approach
Manipulative reduction in the emergency department and angiography
Urgent reduction of the fracture, followed by an on-table angiogram or arterial exploration

questions.text: Seven hours ago, a 32-year-old man who was not wearing a seat belt was injured when his car struck a power pole. He needed to be extricated from the vehicle. Examination reveals absent pulses in the left foot, the thigh is swollen and tender, and a closed fracture is noted. Radiographs are shown below. Doppler examination reveals no significant flow distal to the fracture site. Treatment should include which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has a probable vascular injury based on absent pulses and a Doppler examination. Since 7 hours have elapsed since the injury, immediate restoration of blood flow is imperative.

Angiography with the fracture in a displaced position will be misleading. The patient should undergo urgent reduction of the fracture and an on-table angiogram or arterial exploration, followed by fracture and vascular repair.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no 130-132

choices.text: This woman most probably has a vulval malignancy
She is likely aged 35-40 years, the peak age of incidence for vulval malignancy
This lesion is easily amenable to cure by simple vulvectomy
Radiotherapy is the most suitable modality of treatment for this woman's condition

questions.text: Picture shows a vulva with extensive ulcer, true regarding this is -
questions.solution:
Treatment of Vulval Cancer

Postoperative radiotherapy to be given if 2 or more groin nodes involved or the disease free margin is <8 cms

FIGO Staging of Vulval Cancer

  • Stage I - Tumor confined to vulva or perineum (No nodes)
    • IA - Size < to 2 cms stromal invasion < 1 mm
    • IB - Size > 2 cms stromal invasion > 1 mm
  • Stage II - Tumor of any size with spreads to lower urethra, lower vagina or anus, with negative nnodes.
  • Stage III - Tumor of any size spread to lower urethra, lower vagina or anus and regional lymphnode metastasis (i.e., inguinal, femoral lymphnodes involved)
  • Stage IVA - Tumor invades upper urethra, upper vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa or fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral nodes
  • Stage IVB - Any distant metastasis including pelvic LN.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 473, 475

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient presented with Skin lesions as shown in the image. There was a history of winter aggravation. Which of the following nail finding is not associated?
questions.solution:
Melanonychia is brown or black discolouration of a nail. It may be diffuse or take the form of a longitudinal band.

Nail psoriasis

Clinical signs of nail bed involvement

  • Oil-drop sign and salmon patch (Pathognomonic of nail psoriasis)
  • Onycholysis - typically with a pink zone proximally
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis
  • Splinter haemorrhages under the distal third of the nail plate

Clinical signs of nail matrix involvement

  • Pitting (Most Common manifestation)
  • Leukonychia
  • Red spots in lunule
  • Onychorrhexis (longitudinal nail ridge, split, or fissure)
  • Beau lines (transverse lines and ridges)
  • Nail crumbling

Nail Psoriasis Severity Index (NAPSI) is a scoring tool for nail psoriasis.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 35.1, 35.7 - 35.17, 35.32

questions.text: Marked area is representing which of the following area of heart?
questions.solution:
The highlighted area in the question pertains to the tricuspid area of the heart.

Tricuspid Area:

  • Positioned in the lower left sternal border.
  • Represents the location where heart sounds associated with the tricuspid valve can be best heard.
  • The tricuspid valve separates the right atrium from the right ventricle.
  • Its auscultation area provides valuable diagnostic insights into the functioning of the valve and adjacent cardiac structures.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 1, 8th Edition, Page No 333

questions.text: A neonate presented with the features as shown in the image. There was history of collodion membrane at birth. There was history of similar lesion in elder brother. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Harlequin ichthyosis is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that mainly affects the skin. The newborn infant is covered with plates of thick skin that crack and split apart. The thick plates can pull at and distort facial features and can restrict breathing and eating. Genetic changes in the ABCA12 gene cause Harlequin ichthyosis.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome/ Pemphigus Neonatorum/ Ritter's disease is caused by: Staph. aureus.

  • Seen in neonates and infants.
  • Usually follows pharyngeal infection.
  • aureus releases Exfoliative toxins A & B that destroys Desmoglein 1 [Dsg-1]

Fever, irritability and skin tenderness. A widespread erythematous eruption follows which is usually accentuated in the flexures and progresses rapidly to superficial blister formation (Nikolsky positive). The tender skin becomes gathered into folds and, as it shrinks, leaves raw areas which are extremely painful. The condition usually heals within 7-14 days. Mucosal involvement absent.

Epidermal separation occurs superficially.

Nikolsky sign positive- When pressure applied tangentially to skin, overlying epidermis will separate.

Toxic epidermal necrolysis is drug reaction in which >30% BSA is involved.

Seborrheic dermatitis scale has yellow greasy appearance. Pityrosporum ovale >> Malassezia sp. are associated with it.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page 116.3, 116.7

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is being tested in the following patient?
questions.solution:
Testing the hamstring muscles: Hamstring muscles can be tested by requesting the patient to flex the knee against resistance in prone position.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No 100, 101

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient presents to you with blistering on the truncal aspect, associated tense vesicles and bullae on erythematous, urticarial bases. On biopsy, subepidermal blisters associated with eosinophil rich infiltrates are seen. What is the spot diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a 60-year-old male with blistering on the truncal area, accompanied by tense vesicles and bullae on erythematous, urticarial bases, along with subepidermal blisters and eosinophil-rich infiltrates on biopsy, is indicative of bullous pemphigoid (BP).

Clinical features:

  • Autoimmune blistering disorder, common in elderly.
  • Progresses from urticarial-like lesions to tense blisters.
  • Seen on abdomen, groin, extremities, and oral mucosa.
  • Variable pruritus; blisters lead to non-scarring erosions.

Histology:

  • Early lesions show subepidermal blisters.
  • Biopsy reveals eosinophil-rich infiltrates.

Vitiligo presents with the hypopigmentation of skin.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 401

questions.text: The deformity shown in the Xray is seen in which disease?
questions.solution:
• The x-ray deformity seen is consistent with femoral acetabular impingement (FAI), a hip joint issue characterized by abnormal contact between the femoral head and the acetabulum.
  • A mechanical hip disorder where there is abnormal friction between the femoral head-neck junction and the acetabular rim during hip movement.
  • Can lead to hip pain, limited range of motion, and cartilage damage over time.
  • Typically classified into two types: cam impingement (extra bone growth on femoral head) and pincer impingement (over-coverage of acetabulum).
  • X-rays often show signs like femoral head-neck offset reduction, bone overgrowth, or abnormalities in the acetabular rim.

Reference: Essential orthopedics by Manish kumar Varshney, 1st edition, Page no 951

questions.text: Identify the following image:
questions.solution:
• These are Langer's lines.
  • The pattern of fiber arrangement of the dense feltwork of intimately intermingled dermal collagen and elastic fibers is called the cleavage direction or lines of cleavage of the skin, and their linear representation on the skin are called Langer's lines, which is almost same in all persons.
  • Cleavage lines in the dermal layers of skin are mostly arranged in parallel rows. In the extremities they tend to run longitudinally; in the neck and trunk circumferentially.

Reference: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page no 200

questions.text: Which of the following tracts is responsible for positive symptoms of Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Schizophrenia is a complex mental disorder characterized by a range of symptoms, including positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) and negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, flat affect).

Positive symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations and delusions, are thought to be primarily associated with dysregulation of the mesolimbic dopaminergic tract. Overactivity of this pathway can lead to an increase in dopamine transmission in certain brain regions, contributing to positive symptoms.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 37

questions.text: A 1 year old boy was sleeping in his crutch when parents noticed shaky breathing of the child with no response to stimulation. The body had rashes as shown below. The features are highly suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The characteristic extensive ecchymotic non-blanching rash was strongly suggestive of meningococcal septicemia, which can be confirmed from blood cultures.

A non-blanching rash may also be found in Henoch-Schönlein purpura, idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura and viral infection, in association with streptococcal sore throat, and as a drug reaction or accidental or non-accidental injury, but the rapid progression is more likely with meningococcemia.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 1358

questions.text: A child had a sore throat a few days ago. Now he has developed the following skin lesions. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The tiny red pinpoint appearance with sandpaper like texture of rash is characteristic of scarlet fever, which usually develops after an untreated pharyngitis caused by streptococcus pyogenes.

It is common in children from five to fifteen years of age

Patients can have fever often with chills, sore throat, sometimes white or yellow patches on skin folds are seen. Pain while swallowing, peeling roughness of skin can also occur.

Penicillin or amoxicillin is the antibiotic of choice to treat scarlet fever. Antibiotics kill bacteria and help the body's immune system fight off the bacteria causing infection

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 210

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibit both Neprilysin and ACE enzymes?
questions.solution:
Vasopeptidase inhibitors

These are the drugs inhibiting two enzymes, ACE and NEP.

Omapatrilat and sampatrilat are the drugs that can be used orally for the treatment of chronic CHF. These drugs possess all the actions of ACE inhibitors and also result in natriuresis due to increased BNP (decreased metabolism due to inhibition of NEP). Major limiting factor of these drugs is angioedema.

Recently, a combination of valsartan and sacubitril known as ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor blocker and Neprilysin Inhibitor) has been approved for CHF.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 485

questions.text: A 23 years old patient presents with the increase in the drooping of the eyelid (as shown in the below given image) as the day progresses. Which of the following drug can be used for differential diagnosis for the cause of ptosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with myasthenia gravis may present in the emergency with muscle weakness. This could be because of the aggravation of their primary problem (myasthenic crisis) or due to an overdose of drugs like neostigmine (cholinergic crisis). The etiology of the two conditions is important to understand because in myasthenic crisis, there is deficiency of acetylcholine whereas in cholinergic crisis, there is excess of acetylcholine.

Edrophonium is an inhibitor of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase and thus, increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The increased availability of ACh causes dramatic improvement in the symptoms of patients with myasthenic

crisis. In contrast, the symptoms of patients with cholinergic crisis worsen with edrophonium (because it further increases ACh in cholinergic crisis). The drug, therefore, is useful to clinically differentiate the actual cause of muscle weakness in an emergency situation.

The reason for preferring edrophonium over other inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase is its short duration of action. This may be desirable for patients presenting with a cholinergic crisis as the worsening in their condition would be only for a short time.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 121

questions.text: The given image shows astrocytoma. What is a false statement regarding the grading of astrocytoma?
questions.solution:
Astrocytoma -

These are infiltrative tumors with a presumptive glial cell of origin.

The WHO classifies astrocytomas into four prognostic grades based on histologic features

  • Grade I - pilocytic astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
  • Grade II - astrocytoma
  • Grade III - anaplastic astrocytoma
  • Grade IV - glioblastoma

Grades I and II are considered low-grade, and grades III and IV high-grade astrocytomas.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 703

questions.text: A 14 years old female patient is complaining of generalized weakness and jaundice. Her peripheral smear is shown below. What are the complications that can occur in this disease?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows the sickle shaped RBCs. So, the diagnosis is sickle cell anemia. Jaundice may be due to hemolysis of RBC.

The crisis seen in sickle cell anemia are -

  • Hemolytic crisis due to Parvo B19 virus
  • Vaso-occlusive crisis due to occlusion of blood vessel by sickle shaped RBCs
  • Acute chest syndrome - This pneumonia-like illness is the second most frequent acute sickle cell-related event. It occurs in >50% of patients, often more than once.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 759

questions.text: A 40-year-old female is suffering from an autoimmune disease for which she has been on medication for 2 years. She later presented to OPD with the features shown in the below figure. Which of the following antifungal is effective in the treatment of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the woman suggest she is suffering from Cushing's disease. The drugs used for this are -

Metyrapone

It inhibits 11-β hydroxylase in adrenal cortex and prevents synthesis of hydrocortisone so that its blood level falls → increased ACTH release → increased synthesis, release and excretion of 11-deoxycortisol in urine.

Aminoglutethimide, trilostane and high doses of Ketoconazole also inhibit steroidogenic enzymes-can be used to treat Cushing's disease when surgery or other measures are not an option. Ketoconazole reduces gonadal steroid synthesis as well.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 319, 844

questions.text:
Match the following.

1. Tuberculous ulcer
2. Non specific ulcer
3. Epithelioma
4. Basal cell carcinoma
5. Syphilis
questions.solution:
The conditions are being matched with their corresponding descriptions.

Tuberculous Ulcer: Non-specific ulcer (a - 2)

Non-specific Ulcer: Tuberculous ulcer (b - 1)

Epithelioma (Squamous Cell Carcinoma): Basal cell carcinoma (c - 4)

Basal Cell Carcinoma: Epithelioma (d - 3)

Syphilis: Syphilis (e - 5)

questions.text: A person comes walking with a short, stooping gait and tremors in his hands. The patient's relative reported a history of being given some medicines some time back after which he developed these symptoms. Which drug could be implicated in this?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced Parkinsonism is likely the most common drug-induced movement disorder and one of the most common nondegenerative causes of Parkinsonism. Any medication that interferes with dopamine transmission may cause Parkinsonism. The 1st generation antipsychotic drugs are dopamine receptor blocking agents, specifically those that block D2.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 924, 971

questions.text: Given below figure shows the mechanism of action of which of the following anti-cancer drug?
questions.solution:
Tyrosine kinase activated by abl-bcr fusion results in CML. This enzyme can be inhibited by -

  • B: Bosutinib
  • I: Imatinib
  • N: Nilotinib
  • D: Dasatinib
  • P: Ponatinib

(mnemonic: BIND Protein)

Ponatinib

Ponatinib is a third-generation BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor.

Imatinib (first generation) lacks efficacy for the more advanced disease phases, and cells with mutations in the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase domain are resistant.

Second-generation inhibitors (nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib) were developed to address these weaknesses, although they do not inhibit the T315I mutant of BCR-ABL that is found in 15%-20% of patients with CML.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 1214

questions.text: Which of the following drugs shown in the graph below has the lowest potency?
questions.solution:
Potency

  • It determines the affinity of a drug for its receptor.
  • In Log DRC, the more the curve is on the left side, the more potent is the drug.
  • In the given figure, the order of potency is A>B>C.

Efficacy

  • It is the maximum response of a drug regardless of dose.
  • In DRC, it is determined by the highest point of the curve.
  • In the given graph, the efficacy of drug A and B is the same but both are higher than drug C.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 63-64

questions.text: What is your clinical diagnosis of this patient having lesion in conjunctiva in HIV positive patient?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma is a type of cancer that can develop in the lining of blood and lymph vessels. It is more commonly seen in individuals with weakened immune systems, including those with HIV/AIDS.

The lesion seen in the conjunctiva of an HIV-positive patient is likely to be Kaposi sarcoma. This cancer can appear as red or purple lesions and may involve various parts of the body, including mucous membranes like the conjunctiva.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 732

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a surgical technique used for scar revision, particularly in cases where contractures or tightness in the skin needs to be addressed.

This procedure involves making a series of Z-shaped incisions in the scar tissue. The aim is to release the tension in the scar, allowing for better movement and reducing the appearance of the scar.

Other Options:

Y-V Plasty (Option B): Y-V plasty is a technique used for scar revision, but it involves creating incisions in the shape of a Y and a V to redirect tension away from the central scar.

V-Y Plasty (Option C): V-Y plasty is a similar technique to Y-V plasty, where the incisions are made in the shape of a V and a Y to change the direction of tension.

W Plasty (Option D): W plasty is another technique used for scar revision, where the incisions are made in the shape of W to break up the line of the scar.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 37

questions.text: The given diagram is showing the posterior relations of the kidneys. Which of the following structures is related to the area marked in yellow?

In addition, the right kidney is related to twelfth rib, and the left kidney to the eleventh and twelfth ribs.

questions.text: Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Given image is of the microgametocyte of P. falciparum. Because the gametocyte of P. falciparum is banana shaped, or sausage shaped with pale blue or pink cytoplasm and a large nucleus.

Macrogametes are - crescentic deep blue cytoplasm, compact nuclear

While in P. vivax, the microgametes are spherical, compact pale blue cytoplasm and a diffuse nucleus.

Macrogamete large spherical deep blue cytoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the table given below?
questions.solution:
Bioavailability

Bioavailability refers to the rate and extent of absorption of a drug from a dosage form administered by any route, as determined by its concentration-time curve in blood or by its excretion in urine.

It is a measure of the fraction (F) of administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in the unchanged form. Bioavailability of drug injected I.V. is 100%, but is frequently lower after oral ingestion because-

  • the drug may be incompletely absorbed.
  • the absorbed drug may undergo first pass metabolism in the intestinal wall/ liver or be excreted in bile.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 22

questions.text: Identify this organism causing diarrhoea.
questions.solution:
Giardia is a common cause of diarrhoea. It is a flagellate protozoa.

It is a common protozoa that inhabits the duodenum and jejunum.

Infective form - cyst

Mode of transmission - Ingestion of cyst

Infective dose is low ingestion of as few as 10 cyst is sufficient to cause infection in human.

Clinical features vary from asymptomatic carrier to fulminant diarrhea and malabsorption.

Trophozoite adheres to the epithelium. They don't cause invasive or locally destructive alteration.

The trophozoite is tennis racket shape, bilaterally symmetrical and all organs of the body are paired.

It has a sucking disc, two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, and an axostyle.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page number 16, 22, 32-36, 98-100, 107-109

questions.solution:
Comparative effects on iv infusion of the following agents -

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a fever, and on examination, the following picture is seen. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is a childhood disease caused by C. diphtheria. It is a gram positive, non-motile, non-sporing, non-capsulated organism.

It is stained by Albert stain, which stains the meta chromatic granules. Organisms are arranged in a Chinese letter pattern.

It has many types, Faucial is the most common. Laryngeal, nasal and cutaneous forms are also seen.

Patients present with swelling in the neck, typically called a bull neck appearance. It occurs in faucial diphtheria.

Culture can be done on Loeffler serum slope, Tellurite blood agar

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 237

questions.text: Following image shows a syndrome which is associated with narrowing of the anterior chamber angle. Identify the syndrome.
questions.solution:
Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of a fibrillar material in the anterior segment of the eye. Although the origin of this material is not precisely known, it probably arises from multiple sources as part of a generalized basement membrane disorder. Deposition of pseudoexfoliation material on the lens zonules may lead to zonular weakness. The anterior chamber angle is often narrow in patients with pseudoexfoliation, presumably as a result of anterior movement of the lens-iris diaphragm related to zonular weakness. Pigment dispersion syndrome, UGH syndrome, and Sturge-Weber syndrome generally have an open angle, and narrowing of the anterior chamber angle is not typically observed in these syndromes.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Page no 302

questions.text: Following clinical picture is produced by -
questions.solution:
Tooth decay is characteristically caused by Streptococcus mutans (A viridans group streptococcus)/ GAS (Group A streptococcus)

It can cause a range of infections like pharyngitis, tonsillitis, scarlet fever, impetigo and cellulitis.

There are more than 120 stains of group A streptococcus bacteria, the majority of illnesses caused by GAS bacteria are mild. Sometimes, GAS infections cause severe, life threatening symptoms.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 211
