questions.text: Following test is performed in what condition?
questions.solution:
Swinging flashlight test-

It is performed when relative afferent pathway defect is suspected in one eye (unilateral optic nerve lesion with good vision). To perform this test, a bright flash light is shone on to one pupil and constriction is noted. Then the flash light is quickly moved to the contralateral pupil and response noted. This swinging to-and-fro of flash light is repeated several times while observing the pupillary response. Normally, both pupils constrict equally and the pupil to which light is transferred remains tightly constricted. In the presence of a relative afferent pathway defect in one eye, the affected pupil will dilate when the flash light is moved from the normal eye to the abnormal eye. This response is called 'Marcus Gunn pupil' or a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). It is the earliest indication of optic nerve disease even in the presence of normal visual acuity.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 5th edition, Page no 474

questions.text: A 36 years old male presented with fever and headache for 3 days. His BP is 90/60 mm of Hg and examination revealed the following rash on the legs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture suggested here Meningitis with typical purpuric rash is seen in meningococcemia due to Neisseria meningitidis.

N meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus (Half-moon shaped) and it ferments glucose and maltose.

Blood or CSF are collected for diagnosis.

CSF gram stain shows Gram negative diplococci.

Growth occurs on blood agar, trypticase soy agar, supplemented chocolate agar and Mueller Hilton agar.

On blood agar they produce greyish, non hemolytic, round convex, smooth, moist and glistening with clearly defined edges.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 229

questions.text: The given image shows the most common late complication of cataract surgery. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Complications of cataract surgery

  • Posterior capsular tear with nucleus drop
  • Vitreous loss
  • Retinal detachment
  • Postoperative uveitis
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome (TASS)
  • Cystoid macular oedema
  • Striate keratopathy
  • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy due to endothelial decompensation
  • PCO

Posterior capsule opacification (PCO): The posterior capsule behind the lens may opacify months or years after cataract surgery leading to visual impairment.

  • Morphological types are Elschnig's pearls and Soemmering's ring.
  • Treatment is Nd:YAG capsulotomy

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th edition, Page no 293

questions.text: The egg in the following picture belongs to which parasite?
questions.solution:
Egg in the picture is oval and has terminal spine which is characteristic of S. haematobium. It is a species of digenetic trematode belonging to a group of blood flukes.

It is found in Africa and the Middle East. It is a major agent of schistosomiasis.

It is the most prevalent parasitic infection in humans.

Clinical features - children who are repeatedly infected can develop anemia, malnutrition, and learning difficulties.

After years of infection, the parasite can also damage the liver, intestine, lung and bladder.

This parasite is associated with development of Bladder cancer.

Reference: Apurva shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, page no155

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a history of left-side hemiplegia, drowsiness, and lethargy. His radio imaging shows an area of low density on the right parietotemporal area. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is an arteriovenous malformation that results from abnormal communication between one or several cerebral arteries and the vein of Galen.

The most common clinical manifestation is heart failure due to high flow through the malformation. It can cause progressive hydrocephalus as a result of increasing venous pressure or of compression of the sylvian aqueduct.

Definitive diagnosis is by cranial tomography or MRI scan and by angiography.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2930

questions.text: Identify the injured nerve.
questions.solution:
Complete and total paralysis of the third cranial nerve results in:

  • Ptosis, i.e., drooping of the upper eyelid
  • Lateral squint
  • Dilatation of the pupil
  • Loss of accommodation
  • Slight proptosis, i.e., forward projection of the eye
  • Diplopia or double vision
  • Ptosis or drooping of upper eyelid due to paralysis of voluntary part of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle
  • Pupillary light reflex in affected eye is absent
  • Dilatation of pupil due to paralysis of parasympathetic fibers to sphincter pupillae muscle
  • Eyeball gets turned downwards and laterally due to unopposed action of lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles
  • Loss of accommodation due to paralysis of ciliary muscles. Pupil dilates and becomes fixed to light

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No 71

questions.text: A 7 years old boy comes with the following type of lesions. Mother says that the colour of lesions is changing every hour. Sometimes it becomes blue and itchy. The child has been on Ampicillin for sore throat for the last 3 days. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case the child probably has EM (erythema multiforme) following Ampicillin treatment.

EM has numerous morphological manifestations on the skin, varying from erythematous macules, papules, vesicles, bullae, or urticaria appearing plaques to patches of confluent erythema. A burning sensation or pruritus may be present.

The diagnosis of EM is established by finding the classic lesion: doughnut-shaped, target-like (iris or bull's-eye) papules with an erythematous outer border, an inner pale ring, and a dusky purple to necrotic center. The eruption often appears initially as red macules or urticarial plaques that expand centrifugally to form lesions up to 2 cm in diameter with a dusky to necrotic center.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 3141

choices.text: A is associated with less likelihood of adhesion formation to bowel or omentum
B allows for easy entry into the uterus when there is fibroid in the lower segment
B is associated with less likelihood of subsequent uterine rupture during pregnancy
A is more commonly used than B

questions.text: Concerning uterine incisions during a Cesarean delivery, the false statement is -
questions.solution:
A low transverse incision (e.g., Pfannenstiel incision) is less likely to result in adhesions to bowel or omentum compared to a vertical incision.

A low transverse incision is often preferred when fibroids are present in the lower uterine segment, as it allows better access to the uterus while minimizing bleeding.

Vertical incisions on the upper segment are associated with a higher risk of uterine rupture compared to low transverse incisions.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 687, 695, 740

questions.text: A 5 months old child is not gaining weight, has no head control and has a large head. She is investigated for the same, all blood investigations are normal. CT head is as follows. What is not seen in the following image?
questions.solution:
Choroid plexus papilloma - This is usually a benign tumor. It arises from the epithelium of the choroid plexus. It is more common in infancy than in older children. Hydrocephalus is the usual manifestation in infancy, and is usually rapidly evolving and accompanied by papilledema. The hydrocephalus is due to increased CSF production and is a communicating hydrocephalus. Excision is the treatment of choice; a shunt is sometimes required. The prognosis is very good.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2457

choices.text: It is used for emergency contraception
The duration of use is 10 years
It can be used as part of a hormone replacement therapy regimen

questions.text: Concerning the given picture, what is true?
questions.solution:
LNG20 (Mirena)

  • It contains 52 mg levonorgestrel, eluting 20 µg daily.
  • Life span: 5 years
  • Mode of Action
    • Inhibits fertilization
    • Thickens cervical mucus
    • Suppresses endometrium and makes it non-reactive, which prevents implantation
  • Ovarian function is not disturbed by Mirena.
  • Timing of Insertion
    • Within first 7 days of onset of menstruation
    • Immediately after first or second trimester termination of pregnancy
    • Post placental IUCD, insertion: IUCD can be inserted immediately after vaginal delivery or during LSCS before closure of the uterus.
  • Drawbacks
    • Irregular bleeding and oligomenorrhea which are common in first 3-4 months of use
    • Amenorrhea (seen in 20-50% cases by 1 year of use).
    • Not used as an emergency contraceptive

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 270

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl was brought in with a complaint of not moving her left hand since yesterday. An x-ray was done of the left ribs, arm and knee as a part of skeletal survey as follows. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The spiral fracture seen on the X-ray of the left humerus should prompt suspicion of non-accidental injury. Such a fracture is likely to have been incurred through a twisting injury.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) predisposes to easy fracturing. However, there is no evidence of osteopenia seen on the X-ray. OI can be ruled out by taking an accurate family history, enquiring specifically about easy fracturing, the presence of blue sclera, and hearing and dental problems.

A skeletal survey should rule out the presence of other old or recent fractures and the presence of Wormian bones on skull X-ray.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 42

choices.text: Previous termination of pregnancy is a likely cause
This procedure was performed during menses
It is performed under conscious sedation
Hysteroscopy should be done to further evaluate the findings shown

questions.text: The picture shown below belongs to a 25-year-old lady with a 2-year history of inability to get pregnant. Correct statement regarding this is -
questions.solution:
1st test/Initial test - HSG

  • Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) assesses uterine and fallopian tube contour and tubal patency.
  • It shows Mullerian anomalies as well as most endometrial polyps, synechiae and submucosal fibroids.
  • It can also determine tubal patency.
  • Performed in the early follicular phase, within 1 week of cessation of menstrual flow, to minimize chances of interrupting a pregnancy.
  • The procedure is performed by injecting a radiopaque dye through the cervix. As more dye is injected, the dye normally passes through the uterine cavity into the fallopian tubes and then spills into the peritoneal cavity.
  • X-ray films are taken under fluoroscopy to evaluate tubal patency.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs may be given to prevent cramping.
  • HSG may have therapeutic effects. Several studies have indicated increased pregnancy rates for several months after the procedure.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics (doxycycline, 100 mg orally twice daily for 5 to 7 days) are advisable when the patient has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease or when hydrosalpinges are identified during the study.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th Edition, Page no 111, 112, 251

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy comes with redness on the right side of the face as well as ear. It has been present since birth but in the last 2 days it has gotten redder. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is usually present as enlarged visible blood vessels with pale atrophic skin. It can occur anywhere on the body. It is associated with Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome and Parker-Weber syndrome, but can occur on its own.

Progressive hypertrophy, which may lead to heart failure, may accompany arteriovenous malformations.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 3299

questions.text: A 30 years old chronic alcoholic patient presented with 14- 15 episodes of vomiting followed by brisk bleeding from mouth. This patient undergoes Upper GI endoscopy and the image is shown below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Mallory-Weiss tear is a linear mucosal rent near or across the gastroesophageal junction that is often associated with retching or vomiting.

When the tear disrupts a submucosal arteriole, brisk hemorrhage may result.

Endoscopy is the best method for diagnosis, and an actively bleeding tear can be treated endoscopically with coaptive coagulation, band ligation, or hemoclips, with or without epinephrine injection.

Unlike peptic ulcer, a Mallory-Weiss tear with a nonbleeding sentinel clot in its base rarely rebleeds and thus does not necessitate endoscopic therapy.

Reference: Harrison's principal of medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2406

choices.text: This is an aggressive malignant tumour of Merkel cells
It is four times more common in women than in men
Treatment is with wide local excision

questions.text: All are true about & the tumour seen in the image, except -
questions.solution:
Merkel cell tumor- (dermal mechanoreceptor)

This is an aggressive malignant tumour of Merkel cells and usually affects the elderly. It is four times more common in women than in men

Treatment is with wide local excision, aiming for a 25- to 30-mm margin, followed by radiotherapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 659

choices.text: Perform closed reduction of the radius, then immobilize the forearm in a long arm cast in supination
Perform open reduction and internal fixation of the radius, then assess the proximal radioulnar joint for instability, and percutaneously fix the proximal radioulnar joint if instability persists
Perform open reduction and internal fixation of the radius, then assess the distal radioulnar joint for instability, and percutaneously fix the distal radioulnar joint if instability persists

questions.text: A 28-year-old man sustains blunt trauma to his forearm and presents with the injury seen below. Definitive management of this injury involves -
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is a Galeazzi fracture dislocation (reverse Monteggia/ Piedmont fracture). There is a fracture of the lower third of radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. The treatment of choice is open reduction and internal fixation with compression plates.

The counterpart of Galeazzi is Monteggia fracture-dislocation where there is a fracture of the upper third of ulna with dislocation of the radial head.

Both of these fractures are fractures of necessity, i.e., it is necessary to perform open reduction and internal fixation for best results.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: A 40 years old female presented with history of bullous lesion over lip and upper limb which leads to hyperpigmentation over the same site. History of medication for joint pain. She noticed similar 3 episodes over the same site. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug reaction. Bulla formation after ingestion of painkiller and similar lesion over same site suggests diagnosis of FDR.

Irritant contact dermatitis occurs over the localized area of topical application.

Erythema multiforme presents with targetoid lesions and oral erosions.

Herpes simplex presents as grouped vesicles around lips. Recurrent herpes labialis may occur.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 47.1-47.6, 118.11

questions.text: Which tendon is most commonly involved in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor pollicis longus (FPL) muscles are most affected. In mild affections only a portion of the FDP undergoes necrosis (usually to the ring and long fingers). In severe contractures, all four digits are involved. With increasing severity, flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) and pronator teres (PT) with wrist extensors are also involved.

Volkmann's ischemic contracture is the result of untreated ischemic injury that causes muscles and nerves necrosis of the involved compartment.

Early diagnosis and fasciotomy are necessary to avoid the development of

Volkmann's ischemic contracture

Etiology -

  • Neglected compartment syndrome
  • Crush injury
  • Fractures associated with vascular injury
  • Bleeding disorders

The muscles supplied by the anterior interosseous artery are most susceptible to ischemic damage because this is an end artery:

Muscles involved - FDP (ulnar half) → FPL → FDS → PT

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no 66,67

questions.text: Which triad is seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Vogt's triad

It is seen in tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder of multisystem hamartomatosis

It contains-

  • Epilepsy
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Mental retardation

It is also known as EpiLoiA

(Epi- Epilepsy, Loi- Low IQ, A- Adenoma sebaceum)

Other cutaneous manifestations include ash leaf macule, shagreen patch, and periungual fibroma

Follicular occlusion triad

It is a triad of acne conglobata, hidradenitis suppurativa, and dissecting cellulitis of the scalp.

Hutchinson's triad

It represents the stigmata of congenital syphilis characterized by interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson's teeth (peg-shaped, notched permanent incisors), and eighth-nerve deafness.

Meltzer's triad

The classic presentation of mixed (types II and III) cryoglobulinaemia is characterized by triad of recurrent showers of dependent palpable purpura, asthenia, and arthritis or arthralgia.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 140.10, 140.11, 141.8, 147.9

questions.text: The type of injury shown in the image is
questions.solution:
• The image shows a Subdural Haemorrhage.
  • Subdural space is very narrow and contains a small amount of fluid permitting the thin and tough arachnoid to move relative to the dura.
  • The cerebral veins (bridging veins) cross this space to reach the sinuses.
  • The arachnoid is attached to the dura by venous sinuses and arachnoid granulations.
  • It is common in childhood or old age.

Reference: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page no 259

choices.text: Up to S2 Segment of spinal cord
T1 to L2 Segment of spinal cord
C8 to L3 Segment of spinal cord

questions.text: What is the extent of the marked nucleus in the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
The marked nucleus, known as the Nucleus proprius, covers the entire extent of the spinal cord.

It lies subjacent to the substantia gelatinosa throughout the entire extent of cord.

Nucleus proprius:

  • Located subjacent to the substantia gelatinosa.
  • Spans the entire length of the spinal cord.
  • Plays a role in processing sensory information and pain modulation.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No 39, 40

questions.text: Based on the mechanism of action given in the below figure at which site does the β-lactamase work
questions.solution:
The four member ring is the beta lactam ring and its integrity is required for antibacterial activity. Beta lactamase break this ring between the N and C=O group and can result in resistance.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 766

questions.text: Which of the following is attached to the marked area?
questions.solution:
Attachments on the intercondylar area of tibia (from before backwards)

  • The anterior horn of the medial meniscus
  • The anterior cruciate (Latin cross) ligament
  • The anterior horn of the lateral meniscus
  • The posterior horn of the lateral meniscus
  • The posterior horn of the medial meniscus
  • The posterior cruciate ligament

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No 27

questions.text: A 35 years old female came to medicine OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. She was prescribed different medicines to curb the symptoms, following which she came back with this symptom given in the below image. Which of the following drug would have caused these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Penicillins

  • Penicillin G is one of the most non-toxic antibiotics; up to 20 MU has been injected in a day without any organ toxicity.
  • Local irritancy and direct toxicity Pain at I.M. injection site, nausea on oral ingestion and thrombophlebitis of injected vein are dose-related expressions of irritancy.
  • Accidental I.V. injection of procaine penicillin produces CNS stimulation, hallucinations and convulsions due to procaine.
  • Hypersensitivity - An incidence of 1-10% is reported. Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin reactions. Frequent manifestations of penicillin allergy are-rash, itching, urticaria and fever. Wheezing, angioneurotic oedema, serum sickness and exfoliative dermatitis are less common.
  • Anaphylaxis is rare (1 to 4 per 10,000 patients), but may be fatal.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 769

questions.text: Identify the following wound type.
questions.solution:
The image shows a lacerated wound. Lacerations are tears or splits of skin, mucous membranes, muscle or internal organs produced by application of blunt force to a broad area of the body, which crushed or stretched tissues beyond the limits of their elasticity. They are also called tears or ruptures.

Other options:

  • Option A: An incised wound (cut, slice) is a clean cut through the tissues, (usually the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels), caused by sharp-edged instruments. The wound is longer than it is deep.
  • Option C: An abrasion (gravel rash) is a destruction of the skin, which usually involves the superficial layers of the epidermis only.
  • Option D: Chop wounds are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp-cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon, like a hatchet, an axe, sword, broad heavy knife, chopper, sabre, or meat cleaver.

Reference: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page no 190

choices.text: Presence of atypical pseudocholinesterase in this patient

questions.text: A 26-years-old male Ramesh presented to emergency with blunt injury to abdomen and crushing of his legs in a road traffic accident. His blood pressure was 80/40 mmHg. Emergency laparotomy was Planned. Succinylcholine was used for intubation and vecuronium for maintenance of muscle relaxation. Anaesthesia was induced by thiopentone and maintained by halothane. However, during the intraoperative period, the patient developed arrhythmias as shown in ECG below. Which of the following is the likely cause of this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine has a high risk of causing hyperkalemia if used in patients with injury to muscles and nerves. The ECG shows changes characteristic of hyperkalemia and the patient also has crush injury, so this seems to be the most likely hyperkalemia caused by succinylcholine.

Reference: Katzung's Basic & clinical Pharmacology, 14th edition, page no 483

questions.text: You notice the following discolouration of urine while collecting the sample of a patient. Which poisoning would you suspect?
questions.solution:
• The urine's colour change indicates potential carbolic acid poisoning.
  • Carbolic acid, used as an antiseptic and disinfectant, can lead to distinctive urine colour changes. Initially colourless or slightly green, the urine can turn green or black upon exposure to air.
  • This is due to the oxidation of phenol, its primary component.
  • Chronic carbolic acid exposure can cause "phenol marasmus," characterized by anorexia, weight loss, headache, vertigo, dark urine, and pigmentation of skin and sclera, including ochronosis in the cornea and cartilages.

Reference: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page 535

questions.text: Colonoscopy performed on a 25 years old woman with eating disorder showed dark brown to black pigmentary deposit in the lining of the large intestine. Histopathology of biopsy revealed pigment laden macrophages within the lamina propria. The woman on probing revealed use of laxatives for the 9 months to lose weight. What could be the probable laxative agent that could have caused these findings?
questions.solution:
Purgative abuse -

Purgatives are often self-prescribed and taken without consulting a physician. Some individuals are obsessed with using purgatives regularly. This may be the reflection of a psychological problem.

Drawbacks of purgative abuse are:

  • Fluid and electrolyte imbalance, especially hypokalaemia.
  • Steatorrhoea, malabsorption syndrome.
  • Protein losing enteropathy.
  • Spastic colitis.

The active principle of Senna stimulates the myenteric plexus to increase peristalsis and decrease segmentation. They also promote secretion and inhibit salt and water absorption in the colon. Skin rashes, fixed drug eruption are the occasional adverse effects. Regular use for 4-12 months causes colonic atony and mucosal pigmentation (melanosis).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 726

questions.text: A patient during induction and intubation of anesthesia suddenly had high ventilation pressures. The capnograph shows graph resembling shark fin appearance. The likely condition you are facing is -
questions.solution:
Measurement of end tidal carbon di oxide concentration and is graph is useful by studying

  • Phase 1: zero baseline during inspiration; a raised baseline indicates rebreathing
  • Phase 2: dead-space gas (containing no CO2) is followed by alveolar gas, represented by a sudden rise to a plateau. Excessive sloping of the upstroke may indicate obstruction to expiration - bronchospasm
  • Phase 3: near-horizontal plateau indicates mixing of alveolar gas. A steep upwards slope indicates obstruction to expiration or unequal mixing, e.g., COPD
  • Phase 4: rapid fall to zero at the onset of inspiration.

Additional features may be present:

  • Superimposed regular oscillations corresponding to the heartbeat
  • Small waves representing spontaneous breaths between ventilator breaths, e.g., if neuromuscular blockade is insufficient

Reference: FRCA A to Z, 5th edition, page no 101

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The genital tubercle is formed from two mesodermal bands which grows round from the dorsal aspect of the foetus in the 3rd week.

These also provide for the musculature of the abdominal wall, musculature of the anterior wall of the bladder and urethra and pubic symphysis.

Failure of these bands to develop properly or to fuse result in a bifid clitoris, ectopic vesicle, divarication of the foreparts of the labia majora, absence of hair bearing skin of the pubes and a split pelvis.

Reference: Langmans Medical Embryology, 13th edition, Page no: 268

questions.text: An experimental new drug L has been developed & approved for constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Based on the mechanism of action shown in the image drug L is likely to be which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
• Mechanism of Action and Pharmacology -

It is a 14-amino acid peptide agonist of the membrane-spanning GC-C. In the intestinal epithelium, GC-C is activated physiologically by guanylin and uroguanylin, pathologically by heat-stable bacterial toxins that cause diarrhea, and pharmacologically by linaclotide.

Activation of GC-C results in increased synthesis of cyclic GMP, resulting in enhanced chloride and bicarbonate secretion into the intestinal lumen, leading in turn to water secretion and enhanced motility. Some cellular cyclic GMP may be exported and may reduce visceral pain by an action on primary afferent nerves innervating the GI tract.

  • Therapeutic Uses and Adverse Effects -

This compound is approved in the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS and chronic constipation in adults at doses of 290 and 145 μg daily, respectively.

  • Common side effects -

Include diarrhea (which can be serious), gas, abdominal pain, and headaches. Linaclotide is contraindicated in children under 6 years old and is not recommended for older children.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 929

questions.text: In a patient with intrauterine death, this is seen in the ultrasonography image. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
The overlapping of bones is the Spalding sign characteristic of IUD.

Earliest diagnosis of IUD is possible by USG -

  • Absence of foetal cardiac activity on ultrasound scan (diagnostic).
  • Decreased liquor amnii.
  • Spalding's sign i.e., overlapping of foetal skull bones due to shrinkage of cerebrum after foetal death

Other signs:

  • Roberts sign: Presence of gas in the foetal large vessels (earliest sign-seen 12 hours after foetal death).
  • Ball sign: Crumpled up spine of the foetus or hyperflexion of the spine.
  • Spalding's sign: Overlapping of foetal skull bones seen due to shrinkage of cerebrum after death of foetus. Crowding of the ribs shadow with loss of normal parallelism.

Spalding sign is seen both on USG and radiology.

Reference: Sheila Balakrishnan, 3rd edition, p 249.
